p: It is astonishing, but little is known about the pathogenesis of mumps [ 75]. The classical picture is that of bilateral parotitis after 7–21 days’ incubation, but in 30% of these cases CNS infection may occur [ 75]. Mumps encephalitis is characterized by perivascular demyelination in the cerebrum, cerebellum, brain stem and spinal cord. The basal ganglia may also be affected [ 75]. In children with mumps meningitis, in contrast to other causes of meningitis, there is an increase of IL-8, IL-10, IL-12, IL-13 and IFN-ɣ [ 3]. Mumps encephalitis is confirmed with a PCR on the CSF, and serum or saliva antibodies can provide supportive evidence [ 10].
